parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate by name, surname, or any other clear identifier.  The content focuses on general energy projects and their long-term impact.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its content is not directed at a specific individual but rather aims to reach a broad audience interested in energy-related issues.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>False. The primary objective of the post is not to influence the vote for any particular candidate in the parliamentary elections. The content focuses on a discussion about long-term energy projects and their societal impact. While energy policy might be a topic discussed during elections, this post does not directly advocate for or against any specific candidate or party's stance on the matter.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>True. The post appears to be journalistic in nature, presenting information on energy projects and their long-term consequences. It links to an article on a news website, suggesting an attempt to inform the public on a relevant topic. The style and content align with informative journalism rather than persuasive political campaigning.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>Not applicable. The post doesn't express a personal opinion; instead, it presents information related to energy projects.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>769255268715581</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, focusing on long-term energy projects and their impact on future generations, does not constitute electoral propaganda.  It lacks direct reference to any parliamentary candidate or party, avoids explicitly advocating for or against any political position, and presents information in a manner consistent with journalistic reporting. The fact that it's a paid advertisement doesn't automatically qualify it as propaganda; the content itself must be analyzed.  The post's aim seems to be public information and discussion on an important societal issue, not influencing votes in the parliamentary elections.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>Romania1.ro</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
